awd_titl_txt: Simulation and modeling of soot formation and transport in turbulent flames
awd_abstract_narration:
1403403
Lignell

Soot emission from flames is a pollutant, a health hazard, and affects heat transfer. Soot formation is a challenging problem that involves non-trivial flame interactions over a wide range of conditions in their size and time.  Efforts are focused on how soot forms in practical flames that are usually embedded in turbulence, such as those in jet engines and furnaces.  Computer-based models will be developed and their validation will be carried out.  Research advances will be communicated through publication, presentation, and on the web.  Graduate and undergraduate students will be mentored and trained in computational combustion.  Elementary school students will be introduced to what engineers do through flame and flow demonstrations that get students to look carefully at how combustion drives society. High school seniors will be mentored by undergraduate students as they participate in a junior-level fluid mechanics course project where groups define a problem, gather and analyze data, and present results.


This work will address problems in turbulent soot modeling by applying three simulation approaches: one-dimensional turbulence (ODT), direct numerical simulation (DNS), and large eddy simulation (LES), in a single study to understand soot formation and transport, and to validate models used in engineering simulations.  Four tasks are considered: (1) implementing consistent soot models into simulation codes; (2) performing ODT, DNS, and LES simulations to understand soot-flame interactions; (3) evaluating subgrid soot models; and (4) educational outreach to elementary and high school students.  However, the only simulation approach that resolves all scales is DNS, which is prohibitively expensive for practical flows.  For DNS and LES, models are needed below certain scales, because fine-scale information is not available.  This work will use ODT, DNS, and LES to understand fundamental soot-flame-turbulence-radiation interactions, and quantify soot transport models.  ODT and LES will be compared to well-characterized experimental jet flames.  The strengths of these models, used together, complement their weaknesses and provide guidance as to where research needed.

por.por_cntn:
Combustion is central to modern society. Approximately 80% of the world’s energy comes from the combustion of fossil fuels. We heat our homes and drive our cars by the energy of the flame. 

Soot formation is an integral part of combustion. Flames are yellow due to soot incandescence, Radiative heat transfer from soot is important in many applications, from power generation to wildland fire spread. This heat transfer depends on soot concentration and temperature, hence, the formation and transport of soot in a flame is important to understanding flames, and hence in the design of safe and efficient processes. In turbulent flames, fuel and oxidizer often mix via molecular diffusion and a flame exists at the stoichiometric point. Soot is a particle with low diffusivity compared to gaseous species, and hence soot can move relative to the flame. This transport impacts the soot temperature, hence formation rates and radiative heat transfer rates.

The soot formation and transport depend on the turbulent fluid motions that mix the fuel, oxidizer, and combustion products. This results in a wide range of length scales (ranging from nanometers to meters), and a similarly large range of timescales. Understanding this process depends on our models for chemical reaction, heat transfer, fluid mechanics, and our ability to accurately model these processes. Current computer simulation techniques cannot capture all of the fluid motions and the detailed chemistry for configurations of interest and are limited to relatively simple flows. Even when such simulations are available they are computationally expensive and there are limited resources available. Such simulations are called DNS (direct numerical simulations). Cheaper simulation approaches cannot capture all length and time scales and have to model the effects of small-scale processes. These simulations are called LES (large-eddy simulation). Modeling these so-called subgrid processes is very challenging and there are no single models that can apply to the wide range of conditions that may occur, such as premixed and nonpremixed flames, flames with extinction and ignition, and flames with soot formation, among others.

In this project, we use simulation techniques to investigate soot formation processes. These techniques include DNS, LES, and the One-Dimensional Turbulence (ODT) model. ODT solves the full range of length and time scales in a turbulent flow, but only in a single dimension. DNS captures all scales, but is limited in size and scope; LES can simulate large scales but must model the fine scales where flame dynamics are active; ODT complements LES by capturing some fine-scale processes, but modeling large-scale turbulent eddies. ODT provides similarly detailed statistical information as DNS, though with some limitations related to the geometry. It is not a replacement for DNS, but can complement DNS as a tool for theoretical investigation of turbulent flames. 

We enhanced the ODT model by adding soot formation models, radiative transport models, and developed a new cylindrical formulation that allows simulation of experimental flames, which is useful for validation studies. Several publications are available or in review detailing the results of the model. In particular, the model has been compared directly with DNS data with good agreement. At the same time, the ODT simulations were around 1500 times less expensive to compute, and this cost difference increases as the size of the flames increase. http://ignite.byu.edu/nsf/images/PO1.png shows previous results comparing the mass fraction of gas originating in the fuel stream for the ODT and DNS.

These results prompted a more detailed study during this project of aspects of soot modeling. For example, http://ignite.byu.edu/nsf/images/PO1.png shows plots of the mean soot reaction rate across a jet flame at four heights. The mean soot rate is computed using different levels of subgrid averaging, similar to what is done in large eddy simulation. The plots show that the reaction rate accuracy decreases as the filter size increases using the standard modeling approach.

http://ignite.byu.edu/nsf/images/PO1.png shows velocity, temperature, and mixture fraction from the new cylindrical ODT model compared to an experimental jet flame. The agreement is seen to be very good and lends confidence to the use of the model.

This project also involved significant educational outreach and inclusion of under-represented groups. One graduate student and seven undergraduates participated in the project. Five of eight of these students were women. Numerous presentations and demonstrations were given to K-12 students both off-site and in research labs. In addition, high school students were involved in a college level Fluid Mechanics course project for several years.
